description: From Middle English goodly, goodlich, gōdlich, from Old English gōdlīċ (“good, goodly”), from Proto-Germanic *gōdalīkaz (“good, goodly”); equivalent to good +‎ -ly. Cognate with German gütlich (“friendly”), Icelandic góðlegur (“benign”).

entries.meaning: (dated) Good; pleasing in appearance; attractive; comely; graceful; pleasant; desirable.
examples: O Sin, thou knowest that all thy shame in her

entries.meaning: Quite large; considerable; sufficient; adequate; more than enough.

description: From Middle English goodly, goodliche, gōdliche, from Old English gōdlīċe (“goodly”), from the adjective; equivalent to good +‎ -ly. Cognate with Middle High German guotlīche, güetlīche.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) In a goodly way; courteously, graciously.

examples: For love of vertue and of martial praise; To which though nobly ye inclined are, (As goodlie well ye shew'd in late assaies)
